Symmetry: An oval is symmetrical about its major and minor axes.\n2. Foci: There are two foci (points) inside the oval, and any point on the boundary is equidistant from these two points along the major axis.\n3. Ellipse-like: While not a perfect circle, an oval is similar to an ellipse but is not necessarily mathematically defined as one.\n4. Area and Perimeter: The area and perimeter of an oval can be calculated using approximate formulas involving the lengths of the major and minor axes.\n5. }
</answer>
pred_input_text:
An oval shape is a two-dimensional closed curve that resembles the outline of an egg. It has the following properties:

1. Symmetry: An oval is symmetrical about its major and minor axes.
2. Foci: There are two foci (points) inside the oval, and any point on the boundary is equidistant from these two points along the major axis.
3. Ellipse-like: While not a perfect circle, an oval is similar to an ellipse but is not necessarily mathematically defined as one.
4. Area and Perimeter: The area and perimeter of an oval can be calculated using approximate formulas involving the lengths of the major and minor axes.
5. Real-world examples: Ovals are commonly seen in sports (like football fields), art, and nature (e.g., leaves, eggs).

These are some basic properties of an oval.
